paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b, an Earth-sized rocky planet on a short tidally locked orbit around an M dwarf, retain any atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: TRAPPIST-1 b phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: 1 rocky exoplanet with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Observed system: one rocky exoplanet (TRAPPIST-1 b) with phase-resolved thermal spectra from JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-rock no-atmosphere model
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Null scenario: bare-rock, no-atmosphere model with minimal heat redistribution, used as baseline for comparison.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: CO2-rich atmosphere scenario: atmosphere model with significant greenhouse gas absorption, particularly probing the 15 um CO2 band.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: O2-rich atmosphere scenario: oxidized composition with weaker CO2 signature constraints, not fully ruled out by current data.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, cloud treatment) affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
Degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation assumptions remain significant.
